Class ec.ezlib.base.BigIntegerSugar 

java.lang.Object
   |
   +----ec.ezlib.base.BigIntegerSugar
public class BigIntegerSugar
extends Object
A sweetener defining extra messages that may be e-sent to an integer.

OTHER_TYPE 
 public static final Class OTHER_TYPE

approxDivide 
 public static double approxDivide(double rec,
                                   double arg)
Always gives back a BigInteger This corresponds to the Java floating-point "/" operator and the EZ "/" operator.

truncDivide 
 public static BigInteger truncDivide(BigInteger rec,
                                      BigInteger arg)
Always gives an integer resulting from rounding towards zero, ie, truncating. This corresponds to the Java integer "/" operator. BigInteger's existing 'remainder' gives the correct remainder from the truncDivide operation. 

      (a truncDivide b)*b + (a remainder b) == a
      [ 5, 3]: ( 1* 3) +  2 ==  5
      [ 5,-3]: (-1*-3) +  2 ==  5
      [-5, 3]: (-1* 3) + -2 == -5
      [-5,-3]: ( 1*-3) + -2 == -5

Therefore, if the result is non-zero, the sign of the result must be the same as the sign of a. This corresponds to the Java and EZ "%" operator.

floorDivide 
 public static BigInteger floorDivide(BigInteger rec,
                                      BigInteger arg)
Always gives an integer, resulting from rounding towards negative infinity, ie, flooring. This corresponds to the EZ "//" operator.

multiply 
 public static Object multiply(BigInteger rec,
                               BigInteger arg)
mod 
 public static BigInteger mod(BigInteger rec,
                              BigInteger arg)
Remainder from the floorDivide operation. 

     (a floorDivide b)*b + (a modulo b) == a
      [ 5, 3]: ( 1* 3) +  2 ==  5
      [ 5,-3]: (-2*-3) + -1 ==  5
      [-5, 3]: (-2* 3) +  1 == -5
      [-5,-3]: ( 1*-3) + -2 == -5

Therefore, if the result is non-zero, the sign of the result must be the same as the sign of b, and so the result ranges from 0 inclusive to b exclusive. This corresponds to the EZ "%%" operator. When b >= 0, it also corresponds to Java's BigInteger.mod().
